topic: Getting to Know Direct and Reported Speech!

definitions.title: Direct Speech
definitions.definition: Direct speech tells exactly what someone said, using quotation marks.
definitions.example: Example: Jane said, “It is my car.”
definitions.explanation: It shows the speaker’s exact words, enclosed in quotation marks.

definitions.title: Reported Speech (Indirect Speech)
definitions.definition: Reported speech tells what someone said without using their exact words.
definitions.example: Example: Jane said that it was her car.
definitions.explanation: When reporting, we remove quotation marks and usually change the tense and pronouns.

definitions.title: Tense Change Rule (Backshifting)
definitions.definition: When the reporting verb is in the past (like 'said'), the tense of the original sentence usually shifts one step back.
definitions.example: Example: 'I work hard.' → He said he worked hard.
definitions.explanation: Present → Past | Past → Past Perfect | Will → Would | Can → Could

definitions.title: No Change in Tense
definitions.definition: If the reporting verb is in the present (like 'says'), the tense of the reported speech usually does not change.
definitions.example: Example: The teacher explains, “Days are longer in summer.” → The teacher explains that days are longer in summer.
definitions.explanation: The meaning is still current or always true, so no backshifting happens.

definitions.title: Pronoun Change Rule
definitions.definition: Pronouns change based on the speaker and listener in the reported sentence.
definitions.example: Example: She said, “I am tired.” → She said that she was tired.
definitions.explanation: ‘I’ changes to ‘she’; adjust all pronouns to fit the new point of view.

definitions.title: Time Expression Change
definitions.definition: Time words also change in reported speech to fit the past context.
definitions.example: Example: today → that day | tomorrow → the next day | yesterday → the day before
definitions.explanation: Adjust time words to reflect when the action happened relative to the new sentence.

definitions.title: Modal Verb Changes
definitions.definition: Modal verbs like ‘can’, ‘will’, ‘may’, and ‘must’ often change in reported speech.
definitions.example: Example: can → could | will → would | may → might | must → had to
definitions.explanation: Some modal verbs stay the same if their meaning doesn’t change.

definitions.title: That-Clause in Reported Speech
definitions.definition: Reported speech often uses the word 'that' to connect the reporting verb and the reported clause.
definitions.example: Example: He said that he was ready.
definitions.explanation: Using 'that' makes the sentence smoother and grammatically correct, though it’s optional in conversation.

definitions.title: Reporting Statements
definitions.definition: We report statements using the reporting verbs like said, told, or explained.
definitions.example: Example: Peter said, “John can do it.” → Peter said that John could do it.
definitions.explanation: Always shift tense if the reporting verb is in past tense.

definitions.title: Reporting Questions and Commands
definitions.definition: When reporting questions, change the word order and remove question marks. For commands, use 'told' or 'asked' + infinitive.
definitions.example: Example: She said, “Close the door.” → She told me to close the door.
definitions.explanation: Reported questions and commands focus on meaning, not the exact wording.
